Title: the thespian catalyst

Scene: The Technique of Acting, Uta Hagen’s Respect for Acting, and Henry Winkler’s Heyyy, I’m an Actor.
Sheldon: Good evening. I’m your guest lecturer, Dr. Sheldon Cooper. I was expecting applause, but I suppose stunned silence is equally appropriate. I agreed to speak to you this evening, because I was told that you’re the best and the brightest of this university’s doctoral candidates. Hmm. Of course, that’s like saying you are the most important electron in a hydrogen atom. ‘Cause, you see, there’s only one electron in a hydrogen atom. Best and brightest, my sweet patootie. All right, let’s begin. Show of hands, who here is familiar with the concept of topological insulators? Don’t kid yourselves.
Good evening, Leonard, Howard, Raj, freeloader.
Oh, yes, you should have seen those young people. Thirsty for knowledge, drinking in my wisdom. I may have changed a few lives today.
Tell me what?
Oh, tweets about my lecture. Hmm. That’s rather unfair. That’s downright cruel. Plus, insects have six legs. Yeah, I’m not familiar with the acronym KMN.
Well, I suppose everyone’s entitled to their own opinion. I think I’ll turn in. I didn’t want to teach those poopy heads, anyway.
It’s a charming illusion, but it does not cheer me up.
No.
Do you realize that teaching is the first thing I’ve failed at since my ill-fated attempt to complete a chin-up in March of 1989?
For instance?
Hmm, no. One slip of the hand, and suddenly I’m sitting in the Engineering Department, building doodads with Wolowitz.
Isn’t that their burden? I’m the one with something interesting to say.
I sense that you’re trying to slow-walk me to an epiphany. Would you mind very much jumping to it?
Acting lessons. Interesting. It might help if I could act as though I care about my students and whether or not they learn.
(Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.
You’re an (finger quotes) actress, correct?
All right. You’re an actress. I need you to teach me.
Perhaps two. I’d like to master the craft.
It has been suggested to me that acting techniques could improve my lecturing, at which, if certain tweets and blogs are to be believed, I suck the big one.
So, when could we start?
I suppose that’s one way to look at it.
Are you going to help me or not?
Oh, I’m sorry, I thought making the transition from actor to acting teacher was the signal that one’s career had reached the end of the road.
I’ll pay you 40 dollars.
(Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny. (Knock, knock, knock) Penny.
Nothing. I was acting.
Yes. In preparation for today’s studies, I read Stanislavski’s An Actor Prepares, Stella Adler’s
How shall we begin?
All right.
Penny, my body and I have a relationship that works best when we maintain a cool, wary distance from each other.
You’re the teacher.
Why not? It seems like you’re improvising your entire curriculum.
Gotcha.
All right.
Action.
Hey, you taught me something. Who would have thought it?
I’d like a frozen yogurt, please.
Yeah.
You do?
All right. Yes. I see a sign. It says Camarillo State Mental Hospital.
It’s the only explanation I can come up with for why you think you sell shoes and yogurt.
Oh, and we’re going to use props?
You have any frozen yogurt?
Yes. I didn’t care for it.
So is the McRib sandwich. I don’t care for that, either.
I’m glad you asked. I took the liberty of adapting a Star Trek fan fiction novella I wrote when I was ten into a one-act play.
Why don’t we leave that for future generations to decide?
It’s the story of a young boy who is transported from the ignorant backwoods of East Texas to the 23rd Century, where his genius is not only appreciated, but celebrated.
Now, in this pivotal scene, Sheldon’s mother, played by you, argues with an emissary of the United Federation of Planets, Mr. Spock, the role I will bring to life.
Why would we want to do that? It’s called the comfort zone for a reason.
I’m sorry. You’ll be Spock?
Very well. I’ll set the scene.

East Texas. A warm summer night. A woman, Mary, stands on a porch. In the distance, we hear a lonesome train whistle. Woo-woo. The droning buzz of cicadas. Zzzzzzzzz. A coyote howls at the moon, frightening sensitive young boys everywhere. Aw-aw-aw! Out in the woods, an owl screeches.
Hoo!

Shelly! Shelly, how many times have I told you not to leave your sciencey stuff out on the porch? Goodness, I’ll never understand that boy. But then again, I’m a religious nut, and my mind is closed to so many things.
Glory be to Heaven, some sort of creature just manifested out of thin air. George, put down that Pepsi can full of bourbon that ain’t foolin’ no one, and get your shotgun!
I’m sorry. I just don’t buy it.
Oh, my, your sudden appearance startles me.
I understand. Oh, Shelly? A man’s here to take you away to the future! Be sure to pack clean underwear.”
Why?
Yes, but he’s going to a better place where he won’t get beat up. So much.
I’m sorry. I just love that line. Even the way you do it.
Oh, Shelly? A man’s here to take you away to the future. Be sure to pack clean underwear.
Mommy, why are you crying? ‘Cause I’m gonna miss you, Shelly-bean, even though you creep the bejeezus out of me.

Well I’m sorry. It’s not my fault. I’m just incredibly smart, and everyone around here is dumber than a bag of rocks. Oh, now, don’t you start crying. You get in that spaceship. Mommy’s late for Indian bingo.
Mommy, I love you. Don’t let Spock take me to the future!
Leonard: I found another tweet from a student at Sheldon’s lecture. Dr. Cooper has taken a relatively boring subject and managed to make it completely insufferable. Plus, he looks like a giant insect.
Wow. How do you get an entire lecture hall to flip you off at the same time?
Oh, Sheldon changed the password. It’s now Penny is a freeloader. No spaces.
Sheldon gave a lecture at the university tonight. We’re reading the reviews.
I don’t know, I kind of promised Howard.
Oh, uh, from the context, we think it means kill me now.
Yeah, it’s weird. Even though he didn’t want to give the lecture in the first place, being rejected by those students really hit him hard.
We might be starting to zero in on your problem.
I’m still not adjusted to how the SyFy channel spells their name now. S-Y-F-Y. That’s siffy.
Hang on. Hang on. Uh-huh. Okay, thank you. Howard was on his scooter, and got hit by a truck. He’s in critical condition.
It’ll be okay. It’ll be okay.
Howard: Look. Listen to this one. Does Einstein’s theory explain why time flies when you’re having fun, but when you’re listening to Dr. Cooper, it falls out of the sky, dead?
Apparently, if you’re Sheldon, all you need to do is turn your back.
Well, picture the Hindenburg meets Chernobyl meets Three Mile Island meets Tron 2.
Actually, we should all share the moment. Raj, if you would.
FYI, I think that’s what Darth Vader said just before he started building the Death Star.
Yeah, Leonard and I are fine, but I think Raj needs to meet a girl really soon.
I just got offered a fellowship at the Weitzmann Institute in Israel.
I know. The only thing is, I’m gonna be gone for two years.
That’s what we’re here to talk to you about. You see, Bernadette has needs.
So, while I’m gone, you’re going to have to satisfy her.
Shh, shh. Listen to me. I’m not gonna make it.
Raj, I don’t have time. Now, pay attention. My last wish is that you look after Bernadette.
Raj: Ooh, somebody took pictures and uploaded them to their Flickr account.
Mmm, I know the feeling. It’s like accidentally walking into a gay bar and then having no one hit on you. It-It happened to a friend of mine.
Thank you, but cute is for bunnies. I want to be something with sex appeal, like, like a labradoodle.
You really think so?
Well, thanks, Bernadette. And just for the record, labradoodles are hypo-allergenic, which is a very sexy quality to those troubled by animal dander.
What?
Dude, that’s incredible!
Aw, I’m gonna miss you. Are you going with him?
What kind of needs?
I say okey-dokey.
Just that I’m definitely not gay.
Uh-huh.
What happened?
Oh, no!
It’ll be okay. It’ll be okay. (Phone rings) It’s Howard. Howard, hello.
Yeah, I’m right here, buddy. How are you?
No, no, no, don’t say that. You’re going to be all right.
Of course, of course. Now when you say look after, you mean…
Excuse me, Bernadette. I have to hear it from him.
Got it. Take care. I guess I have no choice but to make sweet, guilt-free love to you over and over again for the rest of my life.
What?
Oh, right. Good one.
Penny: Hey, Leonard, is your wi-fi down? I can’t get on.
Thanks. What are you guys doing?
Oh. How’d he do?
That bad, huh?
Listening to Dr. Cooper has made me want to start cutting myself again
Oh, please let me tell him.
What?
I’m not an (finger quotes)actress. I’m an actress.
You want an acting lesson?
Okay, where is this coming from?
Yeah, I saw those. They were funny. I printed a few out and put ’em on my fridge.
Okay, just to be clear. You are asking me for help because I know something that the brilliant Dr. Sheldon Cooper doesn’t.
I think it’s the only way to look at it.
Probably. I’m just enjoying the foreplay. Does this mean you are done mocking my acting career?
Forget it.
Saturday, nine a.m. Bring cash.
What’s wrong?
You were acting?
Well, good for you. Come on in.
Well, I thought we’d start with some basic movement exercises. You know, get our bodies warmed up a little.
So I just want you to relax and kind of move around in the space. You know, just do whatever feels natural. Sheldon?
Come on, you got to work with me. We need to get connected with our bodies.
All right, let’s just say we’ve warmed up.
Okay. One of the things that might help you in connecting with your students is being a little more spontaneous. So why don’t we try some improvisation?
This is all about listening and responding.
I’m going to create a character and a situation, and you just jump in when you feel it.
All right.
Okay, it’s not a movie. It’s improv. So no one calls action.

Okay. Uh, no, the shipment has not arrived, and I really need those shoes. They are my biggest seller. Yes, ladies sizes six through ten. Thank you. Oh, sorry, I have to go, I have a customer. Bye-bye. Hi. Can I help you?
Yogurt?
Um, okay, sure. Luckily, we sell both shoes and yogurt here.
Yes. Look up at the sign, and remember, improv is always about saying yes.
What?
Okay, you know what? Let’s just try a different improv. Uh, oh, this time we will be two winos living under a freeway overpass.
You bet. I had dreams, you know. I was gonna be famous. Show everybody back home I could be someone. Now look at me. Want some?
So, did you get a chance to go over the scene I gave you?
Okay, Cat on a Hot Tin Roof is an American classic.
Fine. What would you rather do as a scene study?
And you think it’s better than Tennessee Williams?
Where No Sheldon Has Gone Before.
KMN.
Okay, that’s fine, but let’s try and get you out of your comfort zone.
Okay, the whole point of this is to loosen you up a little, so I’m thinking you’ll play the role of your mother, and I will bring life to Mr. Spock.
It’s only logical.
All right.
Okay, okay. We get it. You set the scene.
Now just read your mother’s line.
Woo-woo-woo-woo-woo-woo. Spock to Enterprise. Transport successful.
Greetings, Mary Cooper. I am Spock.
Just keep going!

We have been monitoring your son Sheldon from the 23rd Century, and we have determined that he is now ready to join us. His unique genius is our best hope for bringing peace to a vast and troubled galaxy.
Okay, okay, let’s try that last line again, and this time, maybe try choking up a little.
Well, you’re losing your son.
All right, come on, just try it my way. Pretend you’re sad to see him go. I’m gonna lead you in. His unique genius is our best hope for bringing peace to a vast and troubled galaxy. That’s your cue.
All right, come on, come on. Put some real emotion into it. Blah-blah, blah, blah, vast and troubled galaxy. Go.
That’s good. That’s good. That’s good.
Okay, I guess we’re improvising now.
Bernadette: Well, that shouldn’t be too hard. He’s such a cutie.
Don’t you listen to them. You’ve got plenty of sex appeal.
I have to stay here for school.
Most of them regular, some of them kind of messed up.
Did you hear? Isn’t it terrible?
They wouldn’t let me in. Oh my Howie.
Okay, Raj, I know you’ve been avoiding me and Howard, and I’m not leaving until you tell me what’s going on inside that little head of yours.
Amy: Not even when I do this? (Pretends to be a fish)
Well, that was the last arrow in my quiver of whimsy.
If this humiliating experience is really troubling you, there are things we could do about it.
Well, the first thing that comes to mind is isolating the part of your brain where the memory is stored and destroying it with a laser.
All right. Have you considered improving your socialization skills, thus allowing you to communicate more effectively with other people?
Fair enough, but in its essence, teaching is a performance art. In the classroom paradigm, the teacher has the responsibility to communicate, as well as entertain and engage.
Perhaps you should consider taking acting lessons.
Howard (to the real Raj who is daydreami: What ya thinking so hard about?
Sheldon (doing nothing): You said to do whatever feels natural. This feels natural. Certainly more natural than what you’re doing.
Leonard (phone rings): Hello? Oh, my God! Is he okay?
Penny (on phone): Mrs. Cooper, hey, it’s Penny. Yeah, I think I broke your son. Hey, hold on. Talk to your mother.
Raj (singing): Like the wild elephant I am trumpeting my love for you!
My heart burns for you like the sun at noon!
Bernadette (singing): Like a hidden flower my sweet fragrance comes into view!
My desert welcomes you like the rainy monsoon!
Chorus of everyone in cafeteria (singing: Hey! You are my heart! My universe! You are my heart! My universe! You are my heart! My universe! My universe!
Raj (out of daydream): Dance number aside, I’m so not gay.
